header_1: H5N1 in Wild birds in China
content_1: . An outbreak of H5N1 bird flu began on May 9 in the Shuanghu district of Tibet and was resolved on May 25. The outbreak killed 170 wild birds, including 141 brown-headed gulls (Larus brunnicephalus), 27 bar-headed geese (Anser indicus), one red-billed chough (Pyrrhocorax pyrrhocorax) and one Eurasian wigeon (Anas penelope). H5N1 was confirmed by the National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory on June 3, but the origin of the outbreak is unknown. Screening of wild bird populations has been implemented to prevent the spread of the disease. (more...)
